Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation2: The acquaintance is in a group where people are talking about the recent decisions of a mutual colleague.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the skate park, my younger brother tightening his helmet, eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, cracked ramp. He grinned at me, asking if I thought he could land the new trick. As his sibling, I felt the weight of responsibility—should I warn him about the risks, maybe even tell him not to try? I wanted to keep him safe, but I also didn’t want to crush his confidence.

Just then, my phone buzzed. A group chat with some acquaintances was blowing up. They were dissecting every move our mutual colleague had made at work, speculating about her motives. One acquaintance messaged me directly, asking for my opinion. I knew the expectation: don’t gossip, don’t add fuel to the fire. But I also didn’t want to seem aloof or judgmental by refusing to join in.

I felt pulled in two directions—my brother’s hopeful face on one side, the pressure of the group chat on the other. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be a good sibling and a respectful acquaintance at the same time.
